greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Differences between successive permutations of 1,2,3,4,5 regarded as decimal numbers arranged in increasing order.
comment: We can produce similar sequences of length n!-1 from all the n-set permutations (1,...,n), starting from n=2 up to n=9. The next larger sequence contains always the preceding sequence as its proper prefix. See A219664 for the largest such sequence. - _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 18 2012
See A209280 for the extension of this sequence to 9!-1 terms, and for comments and formulas which apply to this subsequence. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 15 2013
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..119 (complete sequence)
formula: a(n) = A209280(n) for n<5!. See there for more useful relations. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 15 2013
example: a(3) = 18 because if we order these permutations (ascending), then P(4)-P(3) = 12453-12435 = 18
results.author: Ivan Meyer (ivan.mey(AT)gmail.com), May 23 2005
